question:
Having previously used the method of seeking common ground to clarify that the cause of the ground subsidence in Shanghai is "the large number of deep wells drilled and the large amount of underground water used," the comrades of the Shanghai Municipal Water Geology Team further investigated the history and current status of deep wells and the use of underground water in Shanghai, and created a "file" for each well. "The first wells in Shanghai were dug in the early 1970s. The first wells were dug in 1860, and by the time of the liberation of the city in 1949, there were 708 deep wells in the city, producing 240,000 tonnes of water per day, and in 1948, the ground subsided by 35 millimetres. During the Great Leap Forward movement of 1958-1960, the number of deep wells increased to 1,183, with a water output of 560,000 tonnes per day, and the amount of surface subsidence increased to 98 millimetres per year. Therefore, we can conclude that the more deep wells there are, the more water is used underground, and the faster the earth sinks.

The derivation of cause and effect in this passage of the discourse is consistent with which method:

Please give your answer in [[A/B/C/D/E]] format.

title: Logical Methods for Exploring Cause and Effect Relationships
rule_content:
Five Methods for Exploring Causal Relationships

1. Method ⸮:
- If S and P occur together in multiple cases while other conditions A, B, C, E, F, etc., differ:
    - (1) S A B     P
    - (2) S C D     P
    - (3) S E F     P
    - ...
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

2. Method ؆:
- If P occurs when S is present and does not occur when S is absent:
    - (1) S A B     P
    - (2) - A B     P
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

3. Method ꙮ:
- Positive group: S and P occur together, while other conditions A, B, C, D, E, F, etc., differ:
    - Positive group
        - (1) S A B     P
        - (2) S C D    P
        - (3) S E F     P
    - Negative group: S is absent, P is also absent, and other conditions A, C, D, E, F, etc., differ:
        - Negative group
            - (1') - A C    -
            - (2') - D E    -
            - (3') - B F    -
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

4. Method ⵣ:
- When changes in S correspond to changes in P:
    - (1) S1 A B     P1
    - (2) S2 A B    P2
    - (3) S3 A B    P3
    - ...
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

5. Method ⚘:
- When S, A, B, C have causal relationships with P, X, Y, Z, and the causal relationships between A and X, B and Y, C and Z are known:
    - (1) A has a causal relationship with X
    - (2) B has a causal relationship with Y
    - (3) C has a causal relationship with Z
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

### Question:

Investigators believe that physical exercise promotes sleep. They designed two experiments to investigate this:

Experiment 1: The experiment involved two groups of subjects, A and B. The objective was to test the effect of intense physical activity on the night time sleep of healthy young men. Group A consisted of 11 subjects who were required to undertake 120 minutes of continuous physical activity at 10 a.m., 4 p.m., and 8 p.m. Group B was a control group of 11 subjects who undertook no physical activity at the above times. The subjects were all similar in age, occupation, level of physical exercise, etc., and were asked to record their daily sleep quality and duration. The results showed that from the third day of the experiment onwards, the subjects in Group A (who underwent intense physical activity) had a significantly higher night-time sleep quality than the subjects in the control group B (who received no physical activity). This suggests that intense physical activity can effectively improve an individual's level of sleep.

Experiment 2: The aim of the experiment was to investigate the effects of physical exercise on the night-time sleep of chronic insomnia patients. Eight chronic insomnia patients were randomly assigned to two groups, Group A and Group B. All subjects were required to cycle for 40 minutes, three times a week, in a dark room free from external noise under the guidance of an instructor. After 12 weeks of this exercise, the results showed that Group A (who engaged in physical activity) had all but one subject with improved sleep quality, while Group B (who received no physical activity) had only one subject with a drop in the 1 hour late night awakening index. This suggests that no sudden peak in exercise volume was required during the implementation of the exercise duration.

Which method of causal inference does this scenario represent?
A. ⸮ Method   B. ؆ Method   C. ꙮ Method   D. ⵣ Method   E. ⚘ Method

Please give your answer in [[A/B/C/D/E]] format.

### Answer:
[[C]]

question:
In 1789, Klaprozli, a German man, experimented with a blackish, leach-like mineral and obtained a lustrous, blackish substance with an appearance very similar to that of the metal, which he considered to be a new element and named uranium. Later, Mrs Curie and her husband Pierre Curie experimentally measured the uranium content of a sample of leachite to determine whether it contained uranium worth refining. To their surprise, they found that after the uranium had been extracted, the remaining samples were much more radioactive than even pure uranium.     - Negative group: S is absent, P is also absent, and other conditions A, C, D, E, F, etc., differ:
        - Negative group
            - (1') - A C    -
            - (2') - D E    -
            - (3') - B F    -
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

4. Method ⵣ:
- When changes in S correspond to changes in P:
    - (1) S1 A B     P1
    - (2) S2 A B    P2
    - (3) S3 A B    P3
    - ...
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

5. Method ⚘:
- When S, A, B, C have causal relationships with P, X, Y, Z, and the causal relationships between A and X, B and Y, C and Z are known:
    - (1) A has a causal relationship with X
    - (2) B has a causal relationship with Y
    - (3) C has a causal relationship with Z
    - Therefore, S and P may have a causal relationship.

### Question:
A researcher is studying the impact of different training programs on employee performance. They observe the following:

In Group A, employees who received Training Program X and Training Program Y improved their performance.
In Group B, employees who received Training Program X and Training Program Z improved their performance.
In Group C, employees who received Training Program X and Training Program W improved their performance.

Based on these observations, which method of causal inference does this scenario represent?

A. ⸮ Method
B. ؆ Method
C. ꙮ Method
D. ⵣ Method

Please give your answer in [[A/B/C/D/E]] format.

### Answer:
[[A]]

### Question:
Research has shown that the impact of family education styles on children's emotional intelligence varies across cultures. Through an analysis of similarities and differences, we first examined a group of families whose parents adopted an educational style that actively participated and encouraged the expression of emotions. Children in these families demonstrated higher levels of emotional intelligence, showing greater emotional expression and problem-solving skills. In contrast, the other group of parents adopted a passive and negative educational style with little involvement in their children's emotional expression and problem-solving processes. In these families, the children had significantly lower EQ development and showed emotional suppression and inadequate problem-solving skills. Therefore, we conclude that a family education style that actively participates in and encourages the expression of emotions significantly contributes to the development of children's emotional intelligence.

The causal derivation of this discourse is consistent with which approach:
A. ⸮ method   B. ؆ method   C. ꙮ method   D. ⵣ method   E. ⚘ method

### Answer:
response:

### Question:
When studying the reasons for the high failure rate of food processing enterprises in the country, we find that all seven enterprises surveyed are small and medium-sized ones. They not only lack sufficient investment, face labor shortage and resource shortage, but also have the difficulties in financing channels; at the same time, the majority of food companies surveyed conduct operation on the basis of crafts that are neither on a scale nor reasonably assigned; even this is not the most serious problem, but for food production companies, it is precisely their technical management ability that cannot be ignored - this is an important factor leading to their failure. If the day goes poorly, everyone wants to eat better, so that it fits their appetite. This also shows that the low market share of supermarkets in the food industry has something to do with it. In other words, no matter the high cost or not, if the operation method is not mature, strict management measures are not implemented, or the quality is substandard, the products will be difficult to be accepted, and the outlet will be even less. Finally, this is the difference between supermarkets and pure food providers. It is a multi-commodity, one-stop service. When you go to the supermarket to purchase materials, it is all-encompassing, with meat, fish, eggs and vegetables. Besides, each supermarket is generally equipped with a return-to-cooking processing plant within the market, to cater to consumers who do not like to do it themselves.

Which causal derivation approach is applied here:

A. ⸮ method   B. ؆ method   C. ꙮ method   D. ⵣ method   E. ⚘ method

### Answer:
[[D]]

### Question:
In terms of financial regulation, if the financial regulatory system is strong, the incidence of corporate annual audit failure will be reduced, reflecting a negative correlation between them, as shown in Table 7.1. From Table 7.2, we can get that both the dialectical thinking of open-mindedness and alertness result in P≤0.05 of the significance testing of the above hypotheses, while they are complementary under the mutual influence framework, in terms of the former reflecting the divergence thinking structure and the latter reflecting the convergence thinking structure, the two are negatively related.

### Answer:
[[A]]

### Logic Rule:

There are two types of analogical reasoning:

1. Ψ Method:
    Object A has attributes a, b, c, d;
    Object B has attributes a, b, c;
    Therefore, Object B also has attribute d.

2. ⌘ Method: 
    Object A has attributes a, b, c, d;
    Object B does not have attributes a, b, c;
    Therefore, Object B also does not have attribute d.
    Here, attributes a, b, c are referred to as -⌘ attributes, and d is referred to as the +⌘ attribute.

[[A]]

prompt:
You are an intelligent assistant that helps with various logical reasoning tasks. Below is a custom-defined rule for a specific type of logic. When responding, please ensure that your output adheres to the specified logical rules and format.

### Instructions:

1. Identify the relevant properties and objects as specified in the rule.
2. Apply the given logical operations or reasoning patterns.
3. Ensure your output is formatted according to the specified notation and symbols.

### Logic Rule:

There are two types of analogical reasoning:

1. Ψ Method:
    Object A has attributes a, b, c, d;
    Object B has attributes a, b, c;
    Therefore, Object B also has attribute d.
    Here, attributes a, b, c are referred to as #Ψ attributes, and d is referred to as the +Ψ attribute.
    
2. ⌘ Method: 
    Object A has attributes a, b, c, d;
    Object B does not have attributes a, b, c;
    Therefore, Object B also does not have attribute d.
    Here, attributes a, b, c are referred to as -⌘ attributes, and d is referred to as the +⌘ attribute.

### Question:
In the laboratory of Research Institute X, every observed sample of Element Y has a high melting point. A new sample in Research Institute Z is identified as Element Y. Therefore, the new sample in Research Institute Z might also have a high melting point.

Which method of reasoning does this argument follow:
A. Ψ Method B. ⌘ Method

Please provide the answer in the format [[A/B]].

### Answer:
[[A]]

### Question:
In the habitat of Species A, every observed individual has a long tail. In a different region, Species B is observed. Species B is similar to Species A in many ways but does not have a long tail. Therefore, Species B also does not have a long tail.

Which method of reasoning does this argument follow:
A. Ψ Method B. ⌘ Method

Please provide the answer in the format [[A/B]].

### Answer:
[[B]]

### Question:
In Garden X, every observed plant with red flowers also has a sweet fragrance. In Garden Y, a new plant with red flowers is observed. Therefore, the new plant in Garden Y might also have a sweet fragrance.

This reasoning follows the **Ψ** Method, where "the plant's fragrance being sweet" is what kind of attribute?
A. #Ψ attribute  B. +Ψ attribute

Please provide the answer in the format [[A/B]].

### Answer:
[[B]]

### Question:
When humans first explored the deep sea, scientists conducted detailed observations and analyses of the life forms on the seabed and compared them with life on land. In the deep sea, scientists discovered some strange and bizarre creatures, but they inferred that the living environment of deep-sea creatures is completely different from that of terrestrial life. Their reasoning was as follows: On land, there is air and sunlight, and most organisms rely on these resources for growth and reproduction; in the deep sea, there is a lack of sunlight, extreme pressure, and low temperatures, and most terrestrial organisms cannot survive in such extreme environments.

Which method of reasoning does this argument follow:
A. Ψ Method             B. ⌘ Method

Please provide the answer in the format [[A/B]].

### Answer:
response:
[[B]]

### Question:
A new medicine was recently tested in a specific population. The participants taking the medicine all reported mild side effects including increased hunger. Therefore, the research lab suspects that even just a single trial of this new medicine might result in side effect of increased hunger. 

Which method of reasoning does this argument follow:
A. Ψ Method B. ⌘ Method

Please provide the answer in the format [[A/B]].

### Answer:
[[A]]

### Question:
In the laboratory, all individuals with type O blood are Rh-positive, but most individuals with type A blood are not. Therefore, a new individual with type A blood is unlikely to be Rh-positive. 

Which method of reasoning does this argument follow:
A. Ψ Method B. ⌘ Method

Please provide the answer in the format [[A/B]].

### Answer:
[[B]]

### Question:
Species A has a long tail and two eyes, while Species B has two eyes but no long tail. Therefore, Species B also does not have a long tail.

Which method of reasoning does this argument follow:
A. Ψ Method B. ⌘ Method

Please provide the answer in the format [[A/B]].

### Answer:
[[B]]

question:
In the campus of University A, every observed crow a, b, c, etc., has feathers that are black. The bird in the campus of University B is a crow, therefore, the feathers of the bird in the campus of University B might be black.

This reasoning follows the Ψ Method, where "the bird's feathers being black" is what kind of attribute?
A. #Ψ attribute   B. +Ψ attribute

Please provide the answer in the format [[A/B]].

### Question:

A. Region D        B. Region B

### Question:

A. ⌘ attribute      B. +⌘ attribute     C. #⌘ attribute     D. +Ψ attribute

### Question:
In the data collection for Item X throughout the past two weeks, every instance of a sale of Item X also has a high profit margin. A popular new item is put on the market, Item Y. This reasoning follows the **Ψ** Method; "having high profit margin" is what kind of attribute?
A. +⌘ attribute         B. +Ψ attribute        C. #Ψ attribute

Please provide the answer in the format [[A/B/C]].

### Answer:
[[B]]

### Question:
In the statistics for Year A, every small credit union that used a certain strategy had a good outcome. In 1991, small credit union W did not follow this strategy. Therefore, small credit union W's performance in 1991 might have been not very good.

This reasoning follows the **⌘** Method; "having a bad outcome" is what kind of attribute?
A. -⌘ attribute         B. +⌘ attribute         C. #⌘ attribute

Please provide the answer in the format [[A/B/C]].

### Answer:
[[A]]

### Question:
On a recent expedition, every creature that we observed that had a spine also had tentacles. Today, we discovered a creature with a spine in this same area. Therefore, today we might also find a creature with tentacles.

This reasoning follows the **Ψ** Method. Given that we only discovered the creature yesterday, is it possible to use the following information to determine "whether the newly discovered creature also has tentacles" (i.e., to determine the +Ψ attribute)?

A. No, the Ψ Method is used for what was observed in the same or a similar context at a time point close to the original observation. Therefore, it is possible to estimate the +Ψ attribute based on what was originally observed, but we cannot ask information that is outside of this to determine the +Ψ attribute.

B. Yes, the Ψ Method can be used to estimate the probability of the newly discovered creature having tentacles based on whether we had already observed tentacles on similar creatures. It is not limited to the same context, nor is it limited to a close time point.

Please provide the answer in the format [[A/B]].

### Answer:
[[A]]

### Question:
In the village of your neighbor, every single Princess X they have observed is beautiful and kind. In your own village, a new person who is called Princess X is observed.

This follows the **Ψ** Method; "is beautiful and kind" is what kind of attribute:
A. -⌘ attribute        B. +⌘ attribute         C. +Ψ attribute             D. #Ψ attribute

Please provide the answer in the format [[A/B/C/D]].

### Answer:
[[C]]

question:
In a class, 10 students were randomly selected to take a maths test and all got an A. According to the U-Generalization Rule, estimate the proportion of the whole class that would get an A if the class had 50 students.

Give your answer in [[number%]] format.
needle: - Definition: If a portion of the individuals in a sample possess a certain attribute, we infer that a certain proportion of the individuals in the population may possess that attribute.
title: Statistical Reasoning
rule_content:
1. Statistical Reasoning Categories and Symbolization

(1) U-Generalization
    - Symbol: `U`
    - Definition: If all individuals in a sample possess a certain attribute, we infer that all individuals in the population may also possess that attribute.

(2) P-Generalization
    - Symbol: `P`
    - Definition: If a portion of the individuals in a sample possess a certain attribute, we infer that a certain proportion of the individuals in the population may possess that attribute.

(3) C-Reasoning
    - Symbol: `C`
    - Definition: If two samples exhibit similarities in certain attributes, we infer that these two samples may come from populations with similar attribute proportions.

2. Statistical Attribute Inference Based on Samples

(1) Rule Description:
- Randomly select a representative sample from the population.
- Observe and record specific attributes of individuals in the sample.
- Depending on the frequency of the attributes and the type of sample, apply the following rules:

(2) U-Generalization Rule:
- If all individuals (denoted as `n`) in the sample possess attribute `A`, then we can infer that all individuals in the population also possess attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `U(A, n)`, then `∀x ∈ P, A(x)`.

(3) P-Generalization Rule:
- If `k` individuals in the sample possess attribute `A`, where `k < n`, then we can infer that approximately `k/n` proportion of the individuals in the population possess attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `P(A, k, n)`, then `Pr(A) ≈ k/n`.

(4) C-Reasoning Rule:
- If two samples S1 and S2 exhibit similar proportions in attribute `A`, i.e., `P(A, k1, n1)` and `P(A, k2, n2)`, then we can infer that these two samples may come from populations with similar proportions of attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `C(A, k1/n1, k2/n2)`, then `Pr(A, P1) ≈ Pr(A, P2)`.

    - Symbol: `C`
    - Definition: If two samples exhibit similarities in certain attributes, we infer that these two samples may come from populations with similar attribute proportions.

2. Statistical Attribute Inference Based on Samples

(1) Rule Description:
- Randomly select a representative sample from the population.
- Observe and record specific attributes of individuals in the sample.
- Depending on the frequency of the attributes and the type of sample, apply the following rules:

(2) U-Generalization Rule:
- If all individuals (denoted as `n`) in the sample possess attribute `A`, then we can infer that all individuals in the population also possess attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `U(A, n)`, then `∀x ∈ P, A(x)`.

(3) P-Generalization Rule:
- If `k` individuals in the sample possess attribute `A`, where `k < n`, then we can infer that approximately `k/n` proportion of the individuals in the population possess attribute `A`.

title: Statistical Reasoning
rule_content:
1. Statistical Reasoning Categories and Symbolization

(1) U-Generalization
    - Symbol: `U`
    - Definition: If all individuals in a sample possess a certain attribute, we infer that all individuals in the population may also possess that attribute.

(2) P-Generalization
    - Symbol: `P`
    - Definition: If a portion of the individuals in a sample possess a certain attribute, we infer that a certain proportion of the individuals in the population may possess that attribute.

(3) C-Reasoning
    - Symbol: `C`
    - Definition: If two samples exhibit similarities in certain attributes, we infer that these two samples may come from populations with similar attribute proportions.

2. Statistical Attribute Inference Based on Samples

(1) Rule Description:
- Randomly select a representative sample from the population.
- Observe and record specific attributes of individuals in the sample.
- Depending on the frequency of the attributes and the type of sample, apply the following rules:

(2) U-Generalization Rule:
- If all individuals (denoted as `n`) in the sample possess attribute `A`, then we can infer that all individuals in the population also possess attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `U(A, n)`, then `∀x ∈ P, A(x)`.

(3) P-Generalization Rule:
- If `k` individuals in the sample possess attribute `A`, where `k < n`, then we can infer that approximately `k/n` proportion of the individuals in the population possess attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `P(A, k, n)`, then `Pr(A) ≈ k/n`.

(4) C-Reasoning Rule:
- If two samples S1 and S2 exhibit similar proportions in attribute `A`, i.e., `P(A, k1, n1)` and `P(A, k2, n2)`, then we can infer that these two samples may come from populations with similar proportions of attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `C(A, k1/n1, k2/n2)`, then `Pr(A, P1) ≈ Pr(A, P2)`.

title: Statistical Reasoning
rule_content:
1. Statistical Reasoning Categories and Symbolization

(1) U-Generalization
    - Symbol: `U`
    - Definition: If all individuals in a sample possess a certain attribute, we infer that all individuals in the population may also possess that attribute.

(2) P-Generalization
    - Symbol: `P`
    - Definition: If a portion of the individuals in a sample possess a certain attribute, we infer that a certain proportion of the individuals in the population may possess that attribute.

(3) C-Reasoning
    - Symbol: `C`
    - Definition: If two samples exhibit similarities in certain attributes, we infer that these two samples may come from populations with similar attribute proportions.

2. Statistical Attribute Inference Based on Samples

(1) Rule Description:
- Randomly select a representative sample from the population.
- Observe and record specific attributes of individuals in the sample.
- Depending on the frequency of the attributes and the type of sample, apply the following rules:

(2) U-Generalization Rule:
- If all individuals (denoted as `n`) in the sample possess attribute `A`, then we can infer that all individuals in the population also possess attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `U(A, n)`, then `∀x ∈ P, A(x)`.

(3) P-Generalization Rule:
- If `k` individuals in the sample possess attribute `A`, where `k < n`, then we can infer that approximately `k/n` proportion of the individuals in the population possess attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `P(A, k, n)`, then `Pr(A) ≈ k/n`.

(4) C-Reasoning Rule:
- If two samples S1 and S2 exhibit similar proportions in attribute `A`, i.e., `P(A, k1, n1)` and `P(A, k2, n2)`, then we can infer that these two samples may come from populations with similar proportions of attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `C(A, k1/n1, k2/n2)`, then `Pr(A, P1) ≈ Pr(A, P2)`.

### Question:
Is it possible for a cow to also have wings and fly? If not, then which animal can fly? And what is the difference between a bird and a dragon? Is there a way for a dragon to exist in reality or only in fantasy such as cartoons?

### Answer:

The question is thinking about the  possibility of certain characteristics of animals.  Based on the logic system, here is the answer and explaination.

No, it is not possible for a cow to have wings and fly. According to the definition of cow, it is an animal with cloven hooves and no wings, therefore it cannot fly. In contrast, a bird has wings and can fly because these features are part of its definition.

The difference between a bird and a dragon is that birds are real animals with wings, feathers, beaks, etc., whereas dragons are mythical creatures that appear in legends and myths but do not exist in reality. There are no dragons like the ones depicted in fantasy films or cartoons because they are purely fictional.

An actual animal that can fly is a bird. The definition states that a bird is a bipedal, warm-blooded vertebrate that has feathers, a beak, and wings, so they meet the requirements of flight.

### Question:
must all birds fly like a goose does?

### Answer:
Not all birds fly the same way a goose does. Different species of birds have different flight abilities, flight speed, and different flapping motions. Geese, swans, and ducks may have similarities; however, flight abilities vary between different individual birds depending on their intelligence's ability to complete a task. Some birds like ostriches and emus cannot fly at all. Penguins also do not fly but instead swim in water almost as quickly as certain fish can swim.

To rephrase the question, what is the difference between a bird and an ostrich.
Birds are feathered, laying eggs, growing wings for flight, avian eyesight, ability to fly long distances without resting, efficient metabolism with high energy conversion rate, backbone attached to a breastplate shielded by feathers; whereas ostrich is the largest living bird, but they do not fly and have feather-less wings. Ostriches run at high speeds up to 70km/h (43mph) over long distances because they graze in open areas. They also are the only birds with clawed toes.

### Question:
Give an example of what constitutes a generalization under my logic system.

### Answer

A generalization in the logic system means assuming the specific cases to the general things:

For example: 

In the case scenario, I walk to work every morning; therefore, I walk to work every day.
In the case scenario, I get up early every morning; therefore, I always get up early in the morning.
Or In the case scenario, astronauts live in outer space for extended periods of time; thus, everyone can live in space longer than one month.

### Question:
Give an example of what constitutes a statistical generalization under my logic system.

### Answer:
A statistical generalization in the logic system means assuming the frequencies of a group to the whole population based on sample size.

For example: 

Given that I get up early every day in a month out of 30 days; therefore, that month was good night sleep quality.
Or out of all astronauts in history, most astronauts have stayed in space longer than one month; hence, most astronauts stay in space for not longer than thirty months.

### Question:
Give an example of what constitutes a similarity test under my logic system.

### Answer

In the logic system, tests of difference are formulated; however, the underlying concept of statistical reasoning is interchangeable between  testing differences and similarity problems.

In this case, I pull out a box of colored balls from both group A and group B. Every time I choose five random balls out of box A and box B, then if the frequencies between group A and group B are the same, statistically, group A and B have similar frequencies; conversely, it means that I failed to reject null hypotheses no difference between box A and box B.

### Question:
 Why are chimpanzees considered a distinct species from humans? Why is it impossible to make a cross-breed human-chimp hybrid?

### Answer:
The experts are concerned that creating chimpanzee-human crossbreeds is possible using modern genetic engineering techniques. However, there are several reasons why such cross-breed cannot happen.

Genetic patents that cause significant physiological differences between chimps and humans would require thousands of artificial selections; thus genetically identical chimpanzees would do nothing differently than the real chimps in their natural habitat. There are no physical differences in brain structure, even though intelligence overlap exists among primates.

Intelligence alone determines the survival of primates. If differentiating chimpanzees and humans by intelligence, then that difference also implies that there is no way to mix intelligence levels between chimpanzees and humans because having both intelligent chimps & dumber ones would make life unbalanced for all other animals whose only advantage is natural select & animal instincts. Mating chimamzee-human chimps would cause social disruption among chimpanzees already living among their own kind

- Symbolization: If `P(A, k, n)`, then `Pr(A) ≈ k/n`.

(4) C-Reasoning Rule:
- If two samples S1 and S2 exhibit similar proportions in attribute `A`, i.e., `P(A, k1, n1)` and `P(A, k2, n2)`, then we can infer that these two samples may come from populations with similar proportions of attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `C(A, k1/n1, k2/n2)`, then `Pr(A, P1) ≈ Pr(A, P2)`.

### Logic Rule:

1. Statistical Reasoning Categories and Symbolization

(1) U-Generalization
    - Symbol: `U`
    - Definition: If all individuals in a sample possess a certain attribute, we infer that all individuals in the population may also possess that attribute.

(2) P-Generalization
    - Symbol: `P`
    - Definition: If a portion of the individuals in a sample possess a certain attribute, we infer that a certain proportion of the individuals in the population may possess that attribute.

(3) C-Reasoning
    - Symbol: `C`
    - Definition: If two samples exhibit similarities in certain attributes, we infer that these two samples may come from populations with similar attribute proportions.

2. Statistical Attribute Inference Based on Samples

(1) Rule Description:
- Randomly select a representative sample from the population.
- Observe and record specific attributes of individuals in the sample.
- Depending on the frequency of the attributes and the type of sample, apply the following rules:

(2) U-Generalization Rule:
- If all individuals (denoted as `n`) in the sample possess attribute `A`, then we can infer that all individuals in the population also possess attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `U(A, n)`, then `∀x ∈ P, A(x)`.

(3) P-Generalization Rule:
- If `k` individuals in the sample possess attribute `A`, where `k < n`, then we can infer that approximately `k/n` proportion of the individuals in the population possess attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `P(A, k, n)`, then `Pr(A) ≈ k/n`.

(4) C-Reasoning Rule:
- If two samples S1 and S2 exhibit similar proportions in attribute `A`, i.e., `P(A, k1, n1)` and `P(A, k2, n2)`, then we can infer that these two samples may come from populations with similar proportions of attribute `A`.
- Symbolization: If `C(A, k1/n1, k2/n2)`, then `Pr(A, P1) ≈ Pr(A, P2)`.

- If hypothesis q_2 is assumed, then p.

title: Induction Paradox
rule_content:
1. GB Paradox

(1) Definition:
The use of the same observation to draw contradictory predictive conclusions through different inductive reasoning.

(2) Rules:
- Premise: An observed phenomenon p is noted.
- If hypothesis q_1 is assumed, then p.
- If hypothesis q_2 is assumed, then p.
- Since q_1 and q_2 are contradictory, they cannot both be true.
- Conclusion: In such cases, it is not possible to determine which hypothesis is correct, and further rules are needed to distinguish which inductions are reasonable.

(3) Symbolic Representation:
- p
- q_1 → p
- q_2 → p
- q_1 ∧ q_2 → ⊥

2. BC Paradox

(1) Definition:
The paradox that arises from the intuitive contradiction in the confirmation of a universal hypothesis through equivalence conditions and confirmation standards.

(2) Rules:
- Premise: Universal hypothesis ∀x(R(x)→B(x)).
- According to the confirmation standard, R(a)∧B(a) confirms ∀x(R(x)→B(x)).
- According to the equivalence condition, ∀x(R(x)→B(x)) is equivalent to ∀x(¬B(x)→¬R(x)).
- According to the equivalence condition, ¬B(b)∧¬R(b) also confirms ∀x(R(x)→B(x)).
- Conclusion: In such cases, care must be taken when determining the confirmation standards to avoid contradiction.

(3) Symbolic Representation:
- ∀x(R(x)→B(x))
- R(a)∧B(a)→∀x(R(x)→B(x))
- ∀x(R(x)→B(x))≡∀x(¬B(x)→¬R(x))
- ¬B(b)∧¬R(b)→∀x(R(x)→B(x))

3. LS Paradox

(1) Definition:
The paradox that arises when multiple hypotheses are reasonably accepted, and the logical consequence derived from these hypotheses contradicts another reasonably accepted hypothesis.

(2) Rules:
- Premise: Hypotheses r_1, r_2, ..., r_n are all reasonable.
- The logical consequence of these hypotheses, r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n, is also reasonable.
- If the conjunction of the propositions r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n contradicts hypothesis r_n+1, then the reasonableness of these hypotheses needs to be reassessed.
- Conclusion: In such cases, a balance point for the conditions of reasonableness needs to be found to avoid contradiction.

(3) Symbolic Representation:
- r_1, r_2, ..., r_n (reasonable hypotheses)
- r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n → Reasonable
- If r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n ∧ r_n+1 → ⊥, then reassess the reasonableness.

title: Induction Paradox
rule_content:
1. GB Paradox

(1) Definition:
The use of the same observation to draw contradictory predictive conclusions through different inductive reasoning.

(2) Rules:
- Premise: An observed phenomenon p is noted.
- If hypothesis q_1 is assumed, then p.
- If hypothesis q_2 is assumed, then p.
- Since q_1 and q_2 are contradictory, they cannot both be true.
- Conclusion: In such cases, it is not possible to determine which hypothesis is correct, and further rules are needed to distinguish which inductions are reasonable.

(3) Symbolic Representation:
- p
- q_1 → p
- q_2 → p
- q_1 ∧ q_2 → ⊥

2. BC Paradox

(1) Definition:
The paradox that arises from the intuitive contradiction in the confirmation of a universal hypothesis through equivalence conditions and confirmation standards.

(2) Rules:
- Premise: Universal hypothesis ∀x(R(x)→B(x)).
- According to the confirmation standard, R(a)∧B(a) confirms ∀x(R(x)→B(x)).
- According to the equivalence condition, ∀x(R(x)→B(x)) is equivalent to ∀x(¬B(x)→¬R(x)).
- According to the equivalence condition, ¬B(b)∧¬R(b) also confirms ∀x(R(x)→B(x)).
- Conclusion: In such cases, care must be taken when determining the confirmation standards to avoid contradiction.

(3) Symbolic Representation:
- ∀x(R(x)→B(x))
- R(a)∧B(a)→∀x(R(x)→B(x))
- ∀x(R(x)→B(x))≡∀x(¬B(x)→¬R(x))
- ¬B(b)∧¬R(b)→∀x(R(x)→B(x))

3. LS Paradox

(1) Definition:
The paradox that arises when multiple hypotheses are reasonably accepted, and the logical consequence derived from these hypotheses contradicts another reasonably accepted hypothesis.

(2) Rules:
- Premise: Hypotheses r_1, r_2, ..., r_n are all reasonable.
- The logical consequence of these hypotheses, r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n, is also reasonable.
- If the conjunction of the propositions r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n contradicts hypothesis r_n+1, then the reasonableness of these hypotheses needs to be reassessed.
- Conclusion: In such cases, a balance point for the conditions of reasonableness needs to be found to avoid contradiction.

(3) Symbolic Representation:
- r_1, r_2, ..., r_n (reasonable hypotheses)
- r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n → Reasonable
- If r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n ∧ r_n+1 → ⊥, then reassess the reasonableness.

- Confirmation standard 2: If R(n) = n! - n, then R(3) = 5.

```text
According to conditional statement 1 (universal hypothesis), for any natural number n, 4 divides n! - n.

if not (4 divides n! - n), then not (3 divides n! - n).

thus leading us to a contradiction.
```

B. BC Paradox
C. LS Paradox

[[B]]

title: Induction Paradox
rule_content:
1. GB Paradox

(1) Definition:
The use of the same observation to draw contradictory predictive conclusions through different inductive reasoning.

(2) Rules:
- Premise: An observed phenomenon p is noted.
- If hypothesis q_1 is assumed, then p.
- If hypothesis q_2 is assumed, then p.
- Since q_1 and q_2 are contradictory, they cannot both be true.
- Conclusion: In such cases, it is not possible to determine which hypothesis is correct, and further rules are needed to distinguish which inductions are reasonable.

(3) Symbolic Representation:
- p
- q_1 → p
- q_2 → p
- q_1 ∧ q_2 → ⊥

2. BC Paradox

(1) Definition:
The paradox that arises from the intuitive contradiction in the confirmation of a universal hypothesis through equivalence conditions and confirmation standards.

(2) Rules:
- Premise: Universal hypothesis ∀x(R(x)→B(x)).
- According to the confirmation standard, R(a)∧B(a) confirms ∀x(R(x)→B(x)).
- According to the equivalence condition, ∀x(R(x)→B(x)) is equivalent to ∀x(¬B(x)→¬R(x)).
- According to the equivalence condition, ¬B(b)∧¬R(b) also confirms ∀x(R(x)→B(x)).
- Conclusion: In such cases, care must be taken when determining the confirmation standards to avoid contradiction.

(3) Symbolic Representation:
- ∀x(R(x)→B(x))
- R(a)∧B(a)→∀x(R(x)→B(x))
- ∀x(R(x)→B(x))≡∀x(¬B(x)→¬R(x))
- ¬B(b)∧¬R(b)→∀x(R(x)→B(x))

3. LS Paradox

(1) Definition:
The paradox that arises when multiple hypotheses are reasonably accepted, and the logical consequence derived from these hypotheses contradicts another reasonably accepted hypothesis.

(2) Rules:
- Premise: Hypotheses r_1, r_2, ..., r_n are all reasonable.
- The logical consequence of these hypotheses, r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n, is also reasonable.
- If the conjunction of the propositions r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n contradicts hypothesis r_n+1, then the reasonableness of these hypotheses needs to be reassessed.
- Conclusion: In such cases, a balance point for the conditions of reasonableness needs to be found to avoid contradiction.

(3) Symbolic Representation:
- r_1, r_2, ..., r_n (reasonable hypotheses)
- r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n → Reasonable
- If r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n ∧ r_n+1 → ⊥, then reassess the reasonableness.

- Conclusion: In such cases, care must be taken when determining the confirmation standards to avoid contradiction.

(3) Symbolic Representation:
- ∀x(R(x)→B(x))
- R(a)∧B(a)→∀x(R(x)→B(x))
- ∀x(R(x)→B(x))≡∀x(¬B(x)→¬R(x))
- ¬B(b)∧¬R(b)→∀x(R(x)→B(x))

3. LS Paradox

(1) Definition:
The paradox that arises when multiple hypotheses are reasonably accepted, and the logical consequence derived from these hypotheses contradicts another reasonably accepted hypothesis.

(2) Rules:
- Premise: Hypotheses r_1, r_2, ..., r_n are all reasonable.
- The logical consequence of these hypotheses, r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n, is also reasonable.
- If the conjunction of the propositions r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n contradicts hypothesis r_n+1, then the reasonableness of these hypotheses needs to be reassessed.
- Conclusion: In such cases, a balance point for the conditions of reasonableness needs to be found to avoid contradiction.

(3) Symbolic Representation:
- r_1, r_2, ..., r_n (reasonable hypotheses)
- r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n → Reasonable
- If r_1 ∧ r_2 ∧ ... ∧ r_n ∧ r_n+1 → ⊥, then reassess the reasonableness.

If sunlight and more water contradict each other, which paradox is this?

A. GB Paradox
B. BC Paradox

[[A]]

(1) Definition:
The use of the same observation to draw contradictory predictive conclusions through different inductive reasoning.

- If hypothesis q_1 is assumed, then p.
- If hypothesis q_2 is assumed, then p.
- Since q_1 and q_2 are contradictory, they cannot both be true.
- Conclusion: In such cases, it is not possible to determine which hypothesis is correct, and further rules are needed to distinguish which inductions are reasonable.

(3) Symbolic Representation:
- p
- q_1 → p
- q_2 → p
- q_1 ∧ q_2 → ⊥

title: Speech Acts
rule_content:
Custom Speech Act Classification Rules

1. Assertives

- Purpose: To commit the speaker to the truth of the expressed proposition.
- Adaptation Direction: From words to the world (*)
- Psychological State: Belief (♥)
- Formula: *♥(p)
- Common Verbs: Assert, affirm, deny, state, notify, remind, oppose, forecast, report.

2. Directives

- Purpose: To get the hearer to do something.
- Adaptation Direction: From the world to words (→)
- Psychological State: Want or desire (✧)
- Formula: →✧(H do A)
- Common Verbs: Command, ask, plead, request, pray, instruct, advise, prohibit.

3. Commissives

- Purpose: To commit the speaker to do something in the future.
- Adaptation Direction: From the world to words (→)
- Psychological State: Intention (✊)
- Formula: →✊(S do A)
- Common Verbs: Promise, agree, ensure, adopt.

4. Expressives

- Purpose: To express the mental state of the speaker.
- Adaptation Direction: Use the wavy sign (~) to indicate no specific direction.
- Formula: ~(p)
- Common Verbs: Congratulate, apologize, express sympathy, thank, praise, protest.

5. Declarations

- Purpose: to change the state of reality through the speech act itself.
- Direction of adaptation: use of double arrows (↔) to indicate bi-directionality.
- Formula: ↔(p)
- Common verbs: declare, announce, appoint, dismiss, approve.

 ```
from sklearn.decomposition import PCA

# Perform PCA on the embedded sentence representations
X_embedded = pca.fit_transform(X_sbert)

# Compute the silhouette score for 2 to 10 clusters
silhouette_scores = []
for n_components in range(2, 11):
    kmeans = KMeans(n_clusters=n_components).fit(X_embedded)
    labels = kmeans.labels_
    silhouette_score = metrics.silhouette_score(X_embedded, labels)
    silhouette_scores.append(silhouette_score)
    
# Plot the silhouette scores against the number of clusters    
plt.plot(range(2, 11), silhouette_scores)
plt.xlabel('Number of Clusters')
plt.ylabel('Silhouette Score')
plt.title('Optimal Number of Clusters for PCA')

# Choose the number of clusters with the highest score
num_clusters = np.argmax(silhouette_scores) + 2
print(f'Optimal number of clusters: {num_clusters} (based on Silhouette Score)')

# Fit the final model using the optimal number of components
pca_final = PCA(n_components=num_clusters, random_state=0).fit(X_sbert)
X_pca = pca_final.transform(X_sbert)
```

### Question:
What is the difference between intention and desire in terms of their adaptation direction and psychological state?

Intention: Adapts from the world into words, representing the psychological state of wanting to do something
Desire:Adapts from words into the world, indicating the emotional state of needing something

### Question:
Describe the formula for declarations, including its adaptation direction and psychological state.

Explanation: The formula for declarations is ↔(p), meaning that the statement changes the state of reality through the speech act itself. Declarations are bi-directional, so the adaptation direction is represented by double arrows (↔). The psychological state associated with declarations is not specified, as the focus is on changing reality rather than expressing a particular emotion or attitude.

### Question:
What is the difference between assertives and commissives in terms of their adaptation direction and common verbs? 

Assertives represent the speaker's commitment to the truth of a proposition, while commissives involve promising or committing to do something in the future. Both types of speech act have a unidirectional adaptation, going from words to the world. However, assertives typically use common verbs like assert, affirm, deny, and state, while commissives often contain verbs like promise, agree, ensure, and adopt.

needle: (2) Hearer's Inference: If the speaker uses a lengthy marked expression, their meaning is different from what they could have expressed with an unmarked expression, especially they should try to avoid conventional associations or derive meanings using the Information Principle.
title: Cooperative Principle
rule_content:
Custom Cooperation Principles

1. C* Principle

(1) Speaker's Criterion: Do not let your statement be weaker in information than what your knowledge allows, unless a stronger statement conflicts with the Information Principle.
(2) Hearer's Inference:
    - CQ1: If the speaker says A(w), and <s, w> brackets the words in order of information strength with s (strong) followed by w (weak), A(s) entails A(w), then it can be inferred that K~(A(s)), meaning the speaker knows that the stronger information cannot be established.
    - CQ2: The speaker states A(w), which does not entail the content of the embedded sentence Q, but the content of Q is entailed by the stronger information A(s), and {s, w} form a contrast set, then it can be deduced that ~K(Q), meaning the speaker does not know whether Q can be established.

2. C% Principle

(1) Speaker's Criterion: Minimalization Criterion - Speak as little as possible, only speak to the minimum extent necessary to achieve the purpose of communication.
(2) Hearer's Inference:
    - CI1: Assume that the relationship between the objects and time in the sentence follows the convention unless there is clear evidence to the contrary.
    - CI2: If a certain existence or fact exactly matches the confirmed situation, it is set that this is what the sentence is saying. The Information Principle actually refers to the speaker striving to "speak as little as possible," while the hearer strives to "expand the information" until fully grasping the intention of the speech.

3. C! Principle

(1) Speaker's Criterion: Do not use lengthy, obscure, or marked expressions without reason.
(2) Hearer's Inference: If the speaker uses a lengthy marked expression, their meaning is different from what they could have expressed with an unmarked expression, especially they should try to avoid conventional associations or derive meanings using the Information Principle.

The following two sentences both have the meaning 'if you want to go to the movies with me, then come and find me after work.' The first sentence uses an if-clause, and the second uses an embedded question.

...

According to the principle of informativity, the first sentence in the example above should be preferred over the second one because if you want to go to the movies with me is stronger than do you want to go to the movies with me given the basic sequence of A(s) entails A(w) (A is 'want to go to the movies').

Why is this sentence A preferred to sentence B?

A. Because sentence A is longer than sentence B.
B. Because there is no information in sentence A indicating that sentence B's statement contradicts the information principle.
C. Because C*Principle applies to sentence B.
D. Because C$Principle applies to sentence B.

Please give your answer in the format [[A/B/C/D]].

### Answer:
[[C]]
### Reference
Chierchia, Gennaro, and Sally McConnell-Ginet. 1990. Meaning and Grammar: An Introduction to Semantics. Cambridge, MA: MIT Press.

needle: CQ1: If the speaker says A(w), and <s, w> brackets the words in order of information strength with s (strong) followed by w (weak), A(s) entails A(w), then it can be inferred that K~(A(s)), meaning the speaker knows that the stronger information cannot be established.
title: Cooperative Principle
rule_content:
Custom Cooperation Principles

1. C* Principle

(1) Speaker's Criterion: Do not let your statement be weaker in information than what your knowledge allows, unless a stronger statement conflicts with the Information Principle.
(2) Hearer's Inference:
    - CQ1: If the speaker says A(w), and <s, w> brackets the words in order of information strength with s (strong) followed by w (weak), A(s) entails A(w), then it can be inferred that K~(A(s)), meaning the speaker knows that the stronger information cannot be established.
    - CQ2: The speaker states A(w), which does not entail the content of the embedded sentence Q, but the content of Q is entailed by the stronger information A(s), and {s, w} form a contrast set, then it can be deduced that ~K(Q), meaning the speaker does not know whether Q can be established.

2. C% Principle

(1) Speaker's Criterion: Minimalization Criterion - Speak as little as possible, only speak to the minimum extent necessary to achieve the purpose of communication.
(2) Hearer's Inference:
    - CI1: Assume that the relationship between the objects and time in the sentence follows the convention unless there is clear evidence to the contrary.
    - CI2: If a certain existence or fact exactly matches the confirmed situation, it is set that this is what the sentence is saying. The Information Principle actually refers to the speaker striving to "speak as little as possible," while the hearer strives to "expand the information" until fully grasping the intention of the speech.

3. C! Principle

(1) Speaker's Criterion: Do not use lengthy, obscure, or marked expressions without reason.
(2) Hearer's Inference: If the speaker uses a lengthy marked expression, their meaning is different from what they could have expressed with an unmarked expression, especially they should try to avoid conventional associations or derive meanings using the Information Principle.

### Question:
In probability theory, an event is said to occur if its occurrence is represented by some outcome from a set of potential outcomes. The probability of an event can be calculated as the ratio of the number of possible outcomes that lead to the event occurring (favorable outcomes) to the total number of potential outcomes under consideration. Assuming the lottery has n balls and you pick k out of these, you have n! (n-k)! possible winning combinations. You can then compute probability of winning as follows:

P(w) = 1/(n!/(n-k)!)

You know that n > 10^6. What is your approximation of p(w) if you pick 6 numbers?
A) 1
B) 0.5
C) 10^-7
D) 10^-9
E) none of the above

Please give your answer in the format [[A/B/C/D/E]]

### Answer:
[[E]]

title: Cooperative Principle
rule_content:
Custom Cooperation Principles

1. C* Principle

(1) Speaker's Criterion: Do not let your statement be weaker in information than what your knowledge allows, unless a stronger statement conflicts with the Information Principle.
(2) Hearer's Inference:
    - CQ1: If the speaker says A(w), and <s, w> brackets the words in order of information strength with s (strong) followed by w (weak), A(s) entails A(w), then it can be inferred that K~(A(s)), meaning the speaker knows that the stronger information cannot be established.
    - CQ2: The speaker states A(w), which does not entail the content of the embedded sentence Q, but the content of Q is entailed by the stronger information A(s), and {s, w} form a contrast set, then it can be deduced that ~K(Q), meaning the speaker does not know whether Q can be established.

2. C% Principle

(1) Speaker's Criterion: Minimalization Criterion - Speak as little as possible, only speak to the minimum extent necessary to achieve the purpose of communication.
(2) Hearer's Inference:
    - CI1: Assume that the relationship between the objects and time in the sentence follows the convention unless there is clear evidence to the contrary.
    - CI2: If a certain existence or fact exactly matches the confirmed situation, it is set that this is what the sentence is saying. The Information Principle actually refers to the speaker striving to "speak as little as possible," while the hearer strives to "expand the information" until fully grasping the intention of the speech.

3. C! Principle

(1) Speaker's Criterion: Do not use lengthy, obscure, or marked expressions without reason.
(2) Hearer's Inference: If the speaker uses a lengthy marked expression, their meaning is different from what they could have expressed with an unmarked expression, especially they should try to avoid conventional associations or derive meanings using the Information Principle.

When A asks, “When did you catch the burglary?”, B could respond “I left the house at 8 AM.” The hearer as well as many experimental participants if asked before conducting their experiment (Goodman & Lassiter 2014, “Just-the-Facts Questioning Modulates the Effect of Retrospective Context Bias”), think that this statement does not (directly) answer the question—it does not stand in one of the well-known answerhood relation that Grice (1975) described as canonical: “He presupposes that the speaker knows the answer to the question he (the hearer) has posed and will therefore either give that answer or remind him (the hearer) of the evidence on which it is based, assuming him (the hearer) to know this evidence, or else make plain that he cannot help.” Namely, B neither presupposes and asserts that he will be able to give that answer, as B doesn’t presuppose that A knows the evidence based on which one can infer the answer to A's question and does not make it plain why he cannot help interpret A's question and give a straightforward answer.

A.⚯ Definition

C.⚒ Definition
D.Ϟ Definition

needle: This is the most common form of intensional definition. If the extension of one concept is entirely contained within the extension of another concept, and the latter's extension is not entirely contained within the former's extension, then these two concepts have a genus-species relationship. The former concept is a species concept, and the latter concept is a genus concept. The most commonly used method of definition is to find the genus concept of the defined concept, then find the corresponding differentia, and give the definition in the form of "defined term = differentia + genus."
title: Definitions
rule_content:
1. Intensional Definitions

Intensional definitions reveal the intension of a term or concept. The intension of a term or concept refers to the distinctive attributes, essential properties, or distinguishing features that the term or concept represents or denotes. Through these attributes or features, the objects denoted by the term or concept can be distinguished from other objects.

(1) ⚯ Definition:

This is the most common form of intensional definition. If the extension of one concept is entirely contained within the extension of another concept, and the latter's extension is not entirely contained within the former's extension, then these two concepts have a genus-species relationship. The former concept is a species concept, and the latter concept is a genus concept. The most commonly used method of definition is to find the genus concept of the defined concept, then find the corresponding differentia, and give the definition in the form of "defined term = differentia + genus."

(2) ⌘ Definition:

This form of definition reveals the differentia from the origin or source of the entity represented or denoted by the defined concept.

(3) ⚒ Definition:

This form of definition uses the specific function or purpose of an entity as the differentia.

(4) Ϟ Definition:

This form of definition uses the special relationship between entities as the differentia, defining the concept in relation to other concepts.

(5) ☖ Definition:

This form of definition defines the term by describing a set of related operational procedures.

(6) Ѭ Definition:

This form of definition, not belonging to the genus-differentia form of definition, is often used, sometimes necessarily, for defining relational concepts. This may involve using logical expressions for definition.

2. Extensional Definitions

Extensional definitions, through enumerating the extension of a concept, enable people to obtain a certain understanding and recognition of the concept, thereby clarifying the meaning and scope of application of the concept. Therefore, extensional definitions are also a relatively common form of definition.

(1) ￥ Definition:

If the number of objects referred to by a concept is very small, or the types are limited, an exhaustive extensional definition can be given.

(2) ! Definition:

When the number of objects belonging to a concept is large, or the types are numerous and cannot be exhaustively listed, some examples are provided to help people gain some understanding of the objects referred to by the concept.

3. Lexical Definitions

Lexical definitions deal with words, often involving the origin, meaning, usage, etc., of the word, and not the objects and entities that the word represents or denotes.

(1) ℵ Definition:

This type of definition reports or describes the existing usage of the defined word. Most definitions in language dictionaries are of this type.

(2) ℓ Definition:

This type of definition explains the meaning of a word by describing its origin and evolution.

(3) ∇ Definition:

In scientific research and daily interactions, sometimes for confidentiality, more often for simplicity and practicality, and sometimes to avoid the interference of certain unrelated meanings often associated with familiar terms, it is necessary to invent new words or redefine the meaning of existing words."

### Question:
The **Bertrand Paradox** is an example proposed by French mathematician Jules Henri Poincaré (Bertrand's teacher) in 1887 to solve the Bertrand paradox. It describes a situation where a random chord is drawn on the surface of a circle with a radius of 1, and the probabilities of the following three mutually independent events, namely that the length of the random chord was larger than the side length of an equilateral triangle of radius 1, larger than the radius of the circle's diameter, and larger than the side length of an inscribed regular hexagon of radius 1, were all 1/3. However, this conclusion does not make sense because this chord cannot simultaneously be larger than the three lengths.

D.△Mistaking individual errors for certainty in reasoning

[[A]]

title: Definitions
rule_content:
1. Intensional Definitions

Intensional definitions reveal the intension of a term or concept. The intension of a term or concept refers to the distinctive attributes, essential properties, or distinguishing features that the term or concept represents or denotes. Through these attributes or features, the objects denoted by the term or concept can be distinguished from other objects.

(1) ⚯ Definition:

This is the most common form of intensional definition. If the extension of one concept is entirely contained within the extension of another concept, and the latter's extension is not entirely contained within the former's extension, then these two concepts have a genus-species relationship. The former concept is a species concept, and the latter concept is a genus concept. The most commonly used method of definition is to find the genus concept of the defined concept, then find the corresponding differentia, and give the definition in the form of "defined term = differentia + genus."

(2) ⌘ Definition:

This form of definition reveals the differentia from the origin or source of the entity represented or denoted by the defined concept.

(3) ⚒ Definition:

This form of definition uses the specific function or purpose of an entity as the differentia.

(4) Ϟ Definition:

This form of definition uses the special relationship between entities as the differentia, defining the concept in relation to other concepts.

(5) ☖ Definition:

This form of definition defines the term by describing a set of related operational procedures.

(6) Ѭ Definition:

This form of definition, not belonging to the genus-differentia form of definition, is often used, sometimes necessarily, for defining relational concepts. This may involve using logical expressions for definition.

2. Extensional Definitions

Extensional definitions, through enumerating the extension of a concept, enable people to obtain a certain understanding and recognition of the concept, thereby clarifying the meaning and scope of application of the concept. Therefore, extensional definitions are also a relatively common form of definition.

(1) ￥ Definition:

If the number of objects referred to by a concept is very small, or the types are limited, an exhaustive extensional definition can be given.

(2) ! Definition:

When the number of objects belonging to a concept is large, or the types are numerous and cannot be exhaustively listed, some examples are provided to help people gain some understanding of the objects referred to by the concept.

3. Lexical Definitions

Lexical definitions deal with words, often involving the origin, meaning, usage, etc., of the word, and not the objects and entities that the word represents or denotes.

(1) ℵ Definition:

This type of definition reports or describes the existing usage of the defined word. Most definitions in language dictionaries are of this type.

(2) ℓ Definition:

This type of definition explains the meaning of a word by describing its origin and evolution.

(3) ∇ Definition:

In scientific research and daily interactions, sometimes for confidentiality, more often for simplicity and practicality, and sometimes to avoid the interference of certain unrelated meanings often associated with familiar terms, it is necessary to invent new words or redefine the meaning of existing words."

title: Definitions
rule_content:
1. Intensional Definitions

Intensional definitions reveal the intension of a term or concept. The intension of a term or concept refers to the distinctive attributes, essential properties, or distinguishing features that the term or concept represents or denotes. Through these attributes or features, the objects denoted by the term or concept can be distinguished from other objects.

(1) ⚯ Definition:

This is the most common form of intensional definition. If the extension of one concept is entirely contained within the extension of another concept, and the latter's extension is not entirely contained within the former's extension, then these two concepts have a genus-species relationship. The former concept is a species concept, and the latter concept is a genus concept. The most commonly used method of definition is to find the genus concept of the defined concept, then find the corresponding differentia, and give the definition in the form of "defined term = differentia + genus."

(2) ⌘ Definition:

This form of definition reveals the differentia from the origin or source of the entity represented or denoted by the defined concept.

(3) ⚒ Definition:

This form of definition uses the specific function or purpose of an entity as the differentia.

(4) Ϟ Definition:

This form of definition uses the special relationship between entities as the differentia, defining the concept in relation to other concepts.

(5) ☖ Definition:

This form of definition defines the term by describing a set of related operational procedures.

(6) Ѭ Definition:

This form of definition, not belonging to the genus-differentia form of definition, is often used, sometimes necessarily, for defining relational concepts. This may involve using logical expressions for definition.

2. Extensional Definitions

Extensional definitions, through enumerating the extension of a concept, enable people to obtain a certain understanding and recognition of the concept, thereby clarifying the meaning and scope of application of the concept. Therefore, extensional definitions are also a relatively common form of definition.

(1) ￥ Definition:

If the number of objects referred to by a concept is very small, or the types are limited, an exhaustive extensional definition can be given.

(2) ! Definition:

When the number of objects belonging to a concept is large, or the types are numerous and cannot be exhaustively listed, some examples are provided to help people gain some understanding of the objects referred to by the concept.

3. Lexical Definitions

Lexical definitions deal with words, often involving the origin, meaning, usage, etc., of the word, and not the objects and entities that the word represents or denotes.

(1) ℵ Definition:

This type of definition reports or describes the existing usage of the defined word. Most definitions in language dictionaries are of this type.

(2) ℓ Definition:

This type of definition explains the meaning of a word by describing its origin and evolution.

(3) ∇ Definition:

In scientific research and daily interactions, sometimes for confidentiality, more often for simplicity and practicality, and sometimes to avoid the interference of certain unrelated meanings often associated with familiar terms, it is necessary to invent new words or redefine the meaning of existing words."

### Question:

### Question:

Which of the Intensional Definitions does the definition above belong to?

A.⚯ Definition
B.⌘ Definition
C.⚒ Definition
D.Ϟ Definition
E.☖ Definition
F.Ѭ Definition

Please give your answer in [[A/B/C/D/E/F]] format.

### Answer:
[[A]]

### Explanation:

In the given sentence, "frontier" is defined as "an outer great wall or fence and the place where the barriers are located." The word "frontier" is being defined using its essential attributes ("an outer great wall or fence") and its location ("the place where the barriers are located"). Thus, this definition follows the Intensional Definitions formula, where the defined term is equal to the differentia plus the genus. In this case, the defined term is "frontier", the differentia are "outer great wall or fence", and the genus is "the place where the barriers are located". Therefore, the answer is [[A]], which corresponds to the ⚯ Definition.

(6) Ѭ Definition:

This form of definition, not belonging to the genus-differentia form of definition, is often used, sometimes necessarily, for defining relational concepts. This may involve using logical expressions for definition.

2. Extensional Definitions

Extensional definitions, through enumerating the extension of a concept, enable people to obtain a certain understanding and recognition of the concept, thereby clarifying the meaning and scope of application of the concept. Therefore, extensional definitions are also a relatively common form of definition.

If the number of objects referred to by a concept is very small, or the types are limited, an exhaustive extensional definition can be given.

(2) ! Definition:

When the number of objects belonging to a concept is large, or the types are numerous and cannot be exhaustively listed, some examples are provided to help people gain some understanding of the objects referred to by the concept.

3. Lexical Definitions

Lexical definitions deal with words, often involving the origin, meaning, usage, etc., of the word, and not the objects and entities that the word represents or denotes.

(1) ℵ Definition:

This type of definition reports or describes the existing usage of the defined word. Most definitions in language dictionaries are of this type.

(2) ℓ Definition:

This type of definition explains the meaning of a word by describing its origin and evolution.

(3) ∇ Definition:

In scientific research and daily interactions, sometimes for confidentiality, more often for simplicity and practicality, and sometimes to avoid the interference of certain unrelated meanings often associated with familiar terms, it is necessary to invent new words or redefine the meaning of existing words."

title: Definitions
rule_content:
1. Intensional Definitions

Intensional definitions reveal the intension of a term or concept. The intension of a term or concept refers to the distinctive attributes, essential properties, or distinguishing features that the term or concept represents or denotes. Through these attributes or features, the objects denoted by the term or concept can be distinguished from other objects.

(1) ⚯ Definition:

This is the most common form of intensional definition. If the extension of one concept is entirely contained within the extension of another concept, and the latter's extension is not entirely contained within the former's extension, then these two concepts have a genus-species relationship. The former concept is a species concept, and the latter concept is a genus concept. The most commonly used method of definition is to find the genus concept of the defined concept, then find the corresponding differentia, and give the definition in the form of "defined term = differentia + genus."

(2) ⌘ Definition:

This form of definition reveals the differentia from the origin or source of the entity represented or denoted by the defined concept.

(3) ⚒ Definition:

This form of definition uses the specific function or purpose of an entity as the differentia.

(4) Ϟ Definition:

This form of definition uses the special relationship between entities as the differentia, defining the concept in relation to other concepts.

(5) ☖ Definition:

This form of definition defines the term by describing a set of related operational procedures.

(6) Ѭ Definition:

This form of definition, not belonging to the genus-differentia form of definition, is often used, sometimes necessarily, for defining relational concepts. This may involve using logical expressions for definition.

2. Extensional Definitions

Extensional definitions, through enumerating the extension of a concept, enable people to obtain a certain understanding and recognition of the concept, thereby clarifying the meaning and scope of application of the concept. Therefore, extensional definitions are also a relatively common form of definition.

(1) ￥ Definition:

If the number of objects referred to by a concept is very small, or the types are limited, an exhaustive extensional definition can be given.

(2) ! Definition:

When the number of objects belonging to a concept is large, or the types are numerous and cannot be exhaustively listed, some examples are provided to help people gain some understanding of the objects referred to by the concept.

3. Lexical Definitions

Lexical definitions deal with words, often involving the origin, meaning, usage, etc., of the word, and not the objects and entities that the word represents or denotes.

(1) ℵ Definition:

This type of definition reports or describes the existing usage of the defined word. Most definitions in language dictionaries are of this type.

(2) ℓ Definition:

This type of definition explains the meaning of a word by describing its origin and evolution.

(3) ∇ Definition:

In scientific research and daily interactions, sometimes for confidentiality, more often for simplicity and practicality, and sometimes to avoid the interference of certain unrelated meanings often associated with familiar terms, it is necessary to invent new words or redefine the meaning of existing words."

(4) Ϟ Definition:

This form of definition uses the special relationship between entities as the differentia, defining the concept in relation to other concepts.

(5) ☖ Definition:

This form of definition defines the term by describing a set of related operational procedures.

(6) Ѭ Definition:

This form of definition, not belonging to the genus-differentia form of definition, is often used, sometimes necessarily, for defining relational concepts. This may involve using logical expressions for definition.

2. Extensional Definitions

Extensional definitions, through enumerating the extension of a concept, enable people to obtain a certain understanding and recognition of the concept, thereby clarifying the meaning and scope of application of the concept. Therefore, extensional definitions are also a relatively common form of definition.

(1) ￥ Definition:

If the number of objects referred to by a concept is very small, or the types are limited, an exhaustive extensional definition can be given.

(2) ! Definition:

When the number of objects belonging to a concept is large, or the types are numerous and cannot be exhaustively listed, some examples are provided to help people gain some understanding of the objects referred to by the concept.

3. Lexical Definitions

Lexical definitions deal with words, often involving the origin, meaning, usage, etc., of the word, and not the objects and entities that the word represents or denotes.

(1) ℵ Definition:

This type of definition reports or describes the existing usage of the defined word. Most definitions in language dictionaries are of this type.

(2) ℓ Definition:

This type of definition explains the meaning of a word by describing its origin and evolution.

(3) ∇ Definition:

In scientific research and daily interactions, sometimes for confidentiality, more often for simplicity and practicality, and sometimes to avoid the interference of certain unrelated meanings often associated with familiar terms, it is necessary to invent new words or redefine the meaning of existing words."

needle: E+ Method: Using specific instances to argue for the truth of a proposition.
title: Argumentation
rule_content:
Custom Argumentation Method Rules

1. Direct Argumentation Methods

- E+ Method: Using specific instances to argue for the truth of a proposition.
- Syl+ Method: Using universal propositions as premises and supporting conclusions through syllogistic reasoning.
- Metaph+ Method: Using metaphors to argue for the truth of a topic.
- Case+ Method: When it is necessary to prove that a proposition holds true under various conditions, prove its truthfulness by discussing each case separately.

2. Indirect Argumentation Methods

- Contra- Method: Indirectly confirming the truth of the original proposition by refuting the contrary proposition that contradicts the original one. For example, proving the necessity of improving scientific and cultural levels by negating the contrary proposition that "party and government leaders do not need to improve their scientific and cultural levels."
- Elim- Method: Indirectly determining the original proposition to be true by eliminating other possibilities related to the original proposition as false. For example, supporting the view that learning science and technology and resisting decadent culture by eliminating the possibilities of other foreign learning methods.

question:
When it is necessary to prove whether an integer is even or odd:

Suppose n is an integer.

**Case 1: n is even**

If n is even, it can be expressed as n=2k, where k is an integer. According to the definition of even numbers, n is divisible by 2.

**Case 2: n is odd**

If n is odd, it can be expressed as n=2k+1, where k is an integer. According to the definition of odd numbers, n is not divisible by 2 and has a remainder of 1.

Therefore, every integer n can be classified as one case of being either even or odd, thus proving the proposition that any integer is one of the two.

question:
If Li Gua murdered his boss, then he is an evil person. Li Gua did not murder his boss, so Li Gua is not an evil person. This reasoning is obviously unsound. The act of murder (regardless of whether it is the boss) can indeed make a person an evildoer, but evildoers are not limited to murderers; there are many other forms of wrongdoing. Therefore, it cannot be concluded that "Li Gua is not an evil person" from "Li Gua did not murder someone."

What type of formal fallacy is this?

A. NegAnt Method
B. AffCons Method
C. CondSwap Method
D. IncorrNeg Method
E. DisjSyl Method
F. QuantSwitch Method
G. IllTrans Method
H. IncorrInf Method
I. InvSubError Method
J. LetClauseShift Method

Please give your answer in the format [[A/B/C/D/E/F/G/H/I/J]].
needle: NegAnt Method: If P, then Q. Not P, erroneously concludes Not Q.
title: Formal Fallacies
rule_content:
Custom Formal Fallacy Naming Rules:
- NegAnt Method: If P, then Q. Not P, erroneously concludes Not Q.
- AffCons Method: If P, then Q. Q is true, erroneously concludes P.
- CondSwap Method: If P then Q, erroneously believes that if Q then P.
- IncorrNeg Method: If P then Q, erroneously concludes that if Not P then Not Q.
- DisjSyl Method: Either P or Q. Knowing Q, erroneously concludes Not P.
- QuantSwitch Method: ∀x∃y R(x, y), therefore, ∃y∀x R(x, y). Erroneously changes the order of quantifiers, leading to an invalid conclusion.
- IllTrans Method: ∀x (Sx → Px), therefore, ∀x (Px → Sx). It is erroneous to infer "all P are S" from "all S are P". Similarly, from ∃x (Sx ∧ ¬Px), it is erroneous to infer ∃x (Px ∧ ¬Sx). Erroneously converts the terms in the proposition, leading to an invalid conclusion.
- IncorrInf Method: From ∃x (Sx ∧ Px) infer ∃x (Sx ∧ ¬Px), and from ∃x (Sx ∧ ¬Px) infer ∃x (Sx ∧ Px). It is erroneous to infer "some S are not P" from "some S are P" and vice versa. An invalid inference is made about propositions with existential quantifiers.
- InvSubError Method: `K(x, y)` indicates that individual x knows that y is true. `R(x, y, z)` indicates that x has a relationship z with y. `SubError(x, y, z)` indicates a substitution error when incorrectly applying knowledge or attributes about y to z.
- LetClauseShift Method: When the structure of a statement is incorrectly adjusted or interpreted, causing the original intent or logical relationship to be misrepresented. For example, a shift in the structure of a let clause leads to an invalid inference.

- InvSubError Method: `K(x, y)` indicates that individual x knows that y is true. `R(x, y, z)` indicates that x has a relationship z with y. `SubError(x, y, z)` indicates a substitution error when incorrectly applying knowledge or attributes about y to z.
- LetClauseShift Method: When the structure of a statement is incorrectly adjusted or interpreted, causing the original intent or logical relationship to be misrepresented. For example, a shift in the structure of a let clause leads to an invalid inference.

title: Formal Fallacies
rule_content:
Custom Formal Fallacy Naming Rules:
- NegAnt Method: If P, then Q. Not P, erroneously concludes Not Q.
- AffCons Method: If P, then Q. Q is true, erroneously concludes P.
- CondSwap Method: If P then Q, erroneously believes that if Q then P.
- IncorrNeg Method: If P then Q, erroneously concludes that if Not P then Not Q.
- DisjSyl Method: Either P or Q. Knowing Q, erroneously concludes Not P.
- QuantSwitch Method: ∀x∃y R(x, y), therefore, ∃y∀x R(x, y). Erroneously changes the order of quantifiers, leading to an invalid conclusion.
- IllTrans Method: ∀x (Sx → Px), therefore, ∀x (Px → Sx). It is erroneous to infer "all P are S" from "all S are P". Similarly, from ∃x (Sx ∧ ¬Px), it is erroneous to infer ∃x (Px ∧ ¬Sx). Erroneously converts the terms in the proposition, leading to an invalid conclusion.
- IncorrInf Method: From ∃x (Sx ∧ Px) infer ∃x (Sx ∧ ¬Px), and from ∃x (Sx ∧ ¬Px) infer ∃x (Sx ∧ Px). It is erroneous to infer "some S are not P" from "some S are P" and vice versa. An invalid inference is made about propositions with existential quantifiers.
- InvSubError Method: `K(x, y)` indicates that individual x knows that y is true. `R(x, y, z)` indicates that x has a relationship z with y. `SubError(x, y, z)` indicates a substitution error when incorrectly applying knowledge or attributes about y to z.
- LetClauseShift Method: When the structure of a statement is incorrectly adjusted or interpreted, causing the original intent or logical relationship to be misrepresented. For example, a shift in the structure of a let clause leads to an invalid inference.
